member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx
member.summary: Base class for list collections that fire events before and after changes occur.
member.remarks: This class provides a base implementation of the IList and IEnumerable interfaces. The internal implementation of the collection is an ArrayList.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.EventArgs
member.summary: Arguments for collection change events.

remarks.para:
This is the base class for the arguments passed to collection change events. The
is included in the event arguments. The index position of the element that was changed by the event is also included in the event arguments.

Derived classes extend this base class to include an array of objects along with type-safe accessor methods. When the CollectionEx class needs to call the
and
methods, it creates an EventArgs object by calling the
method. Derived classes override MakeEventArgs to create their own type-safe event argument objects.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.EventArgs.#ctor(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.ChangeType)
member.summary: Construct CollectionEx.EventArgs object of a given type.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.EventArgs.#ctor(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.ChangeType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a CollectionEx.EventArgs object of a given type and assigns the collection index value.
member.param: Index position at which the event occurred

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.EventArgs.ChangeType
member.summary: Type of change that caused the event.

remarks.para:
The reason this property exists is to reduce the number of events that collections must declare and manage. If this property did not exist, then the
and
callbacks and their corresponding events in derived classes would mushroom to around 10 callbacks and events.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CollectionEx.EventArgs.Index
member.summary: Zero-based index into the collection at which the event occurred.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.ConnectionCollection
member.summary: List of objects.
member.remarks: A ConnectionCollection can be attached to an object that implements the IPortContainer interface. If it is, the ConnectionCollection automatically synchronizes the connections in foreign symbols when connections are added or removed.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.LayerCollection
member.summary: A collection of objects.
member.remarks: This class implements the ILayerContainer interface, which provides host services for layers.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.ILayerContainer
member.summary: Interface to objects that contain a collection of layers.

remarks.para: This interface provides methods for managing nodes across a collection of layers.
IMPORTANT NOTE: A node can belong to only one layer.

member.summary: Determines if the container has a layer matching the specified name.
member.param: Name of layer to search for
member.returns: true if the layer is found, otherwise false

member.summary: Finds the layer to which the specified node belongs.
member.returns: Layer containing the specified node

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.ILayerContainer.PropertyContainer
member.summary: Property container that the all layers in the layer container inherit.
member.remarks: Nodes in a layer inherit properties from the layer they belong to. Layers inherit properties from the property container referenced by this property.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.AlignCmd
member.summary: Align two or more nodes along a specified vertical or horizontal edge.
member.remarks: The first node in the command's node collection is always the anchor node. The anchor node is never moved by this command. There must be at least two nodes in the node collection for this command to work. A value specifies which vertical or horizontal edge of the bounding box the nodes will be aligned with. For example, if BoxOrientation.Middle is specified then the nodes will be aligned along the horizontal line passing through the center of the anchor node.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MultipleNodeCmd
member.summary: Base class for commands that operate on multiple nodes.
member.remarks: The property contains the collection of nodes that are affected by the command.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.ICommand
member.summary: This interface is implemented by command objects.
member.remarks: A command object encapsulates an action and the data required to perform the action. A command is executed using the and can be reversed using the method.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.IVerb
member.summary: Interface to verb objects.
member.remarks: A verb is an object that performs an action.

member.remarks: This method is called by derived classes in order to create a hashtable containing index positions of nodes in a collection. It is used to implement Undo for commands that must remember the previous position of each node before the command was executed.

member.summary: Returns the saved index position of the given node.

member.returns: Index position of node or -1 if not found
member.remarks: Derived classes that change the position of nodes in a collection use this method to implement Undo. The position of a node can be saved prior to executing the command using the SetNodeIndex method and retrieved using this method during Undo.

member.summary: Saves the index position of the given node.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.LinkCmd
member.summary: Creates a Link object and connects it to two symbols.

remarks.para:
This command creates a new link and adds it to the diagram. It then creates a connection between the tail port of the link and the port specified by the
property. Next, it creates a connection between the head port of the link and the port specified by the
property. The SourcePort and TargetPort are allowed to be null. If the SourcePort is null, then no connection will be created for the tail port of the link. If the TargetPort is null, then no connection will be created for the head port of the link.

Creation of the link can be controller by setting the
property, which is a delegate that is invoked when the command needs to create the link. The LinkFactory can be used to create links containing different shapes and properties. It can also be used to create objects derived from the Link class. The default LinkFactory creates a an object of type Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Link containing a polyline.

member.summary: Default constructor.

member.summary: Construct a LinkCmd object given two ports and an array of points.
member.param: Port to connect to the tail of the link
Port to connect to the head of the link
Array of points to create the link with

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.LinkCmd.Do(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a Link object and connects the tail port and head port of the link.
member.param: Parent node to add the link to
member.returns: true if successful, otherwise false
member.remarks:
If the property is null when this method is called, then a new Link object is created by invoking the
delegate. The Link object is then added to the node passed in the cmdTarget parameter. Next, the tail of the link is connected to the
and the head of the link is connected to the .

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.IPropertyContainer
member.summary: Late-binding interface for accessing dynamic properties.

remarks.para: This interface provides access to the properties of an object. There are several advantages to using this interface. Code accessing the properties of an object do not need to be coupled to the object type; it only requires this interface. Objects that support this interface have flexibility in how it is implemented. For example, a class can support both static (compile-time) properties and dynamic (run-time) properties through this interface. Property inheritance is also an important feature made possible by this interface.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.LayoutManager
member.summary: Base class for layout managers.

remarks.para:
This class provides the basic plumbing for layout managers. A layout manager is an object that controls the positioning of nodes in a model. Each layout manager object is attached to a single model by the
property.

Layout managers can operate one of two modes: manual or auto-update. When the
flag is set to true, the layout manager responds to events in the model by automatically repositioning nodes in the model. The
method can be called at any time to reposition the nodes in the model. If the AutoLayout flag is false, then UpdateLayout must be called manually in order to update the layout of nodes in the model.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Controller
member.summary: Processes input events and translates them into actions on the diagram.

remarks.para: The controller is an object that is responsible for handling input in the model-view-controller architecture. The controller receives input events and translates them into commands that affect the model and view.

The features of a controller are implemented as distinct objects called tools. A tool is an object that implements a slice of functionality for the controller. Tools can be added to the controller using the
method in order to customize the behavior of the controller.

This class is an abstract base class from which concrete controller classes are derived. This class does not does not register any tools. Derived controller classes must override the
method in order to register the tools needed by that specified type of controller.

The controller is responsible for coordinating the activation and deactivation of tools. The
method activates a specified tool. The
method deactivates a specified tool. Tools can be accessed by name with the
method.

The controller is responsible for coordinating the executing of commands. A command is typically executed by a tool when it reaches a certain state during its processing of input events. For example, the
executes an
command when it receives a mouse up event. The controller implements the
interface, which defines the
method used to execute commands. The ICommandDispatcher interface also defines methods to undo commands, redo commands, and manage the undo and redo stacks.

The controller captures all mouse events and performs hit testing on the diagram. Nodes, ports, and vertices hit by mouse movements are tracked by the controller. Tools can access this hit testing information in the controller. In other words, the controller provides basic hit testing services to tools so that each tool doesn't need to implement (and possible duplicate) that hit testing logic. The following properties and methods provide access to the hit testing state information: , , , , , , , , .

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Controller.ActivateTool(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Tool)
member.summary: Activates the given Tool object.
member.returns: true if successful, otherwise false
member.remarks:
This method first iterates through all of the other registered tools (excluding the one to be activated) and notifies each one of the activation by calling . This gives the other tools a chance to suspend themselves or do any necessary cleanup before a new tool becomes active. Next, this method activates the Tool by calling its
method. Finally, it fires the Controller's ToolActivate event.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Controller.DeactivateTool(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Tool)
member.summary: Deactivates the given Tool object.
member.returns: true if successful, otherwise false
member.remarks:
First, this method iterates through all of the other tools (excluding the one to be deactivated) and notifies them of the deactivation by calling the
method. Next, this method deactivates the Tool by calling its
method. Finally, this method fires the Controller's ToolDeactivate event.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Group
member.summary: A group is a node that acts as a transparent container for other nodes.

remarks.para: A group is a composite node that controls a set of child nodes. The bounding rectangle of a group is the union of the bounds of its children. The group is renders itself by iterating through its children and rendering them. Child nodes cannot be selected or manipulated individually.
Members of the group are added and removed through the ICompositeNode interface.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Group.Bounds
member.summary: The group's bounding box.

remarks.para: Always returns the bounds of the group in world coordinates, regardless of what is on the matrix stack at the time of the call.

The bounding box of a group is the union of the bounds of all of its children. This method pushes the group's
onto the matrix stack and then iterates through each child retrieving it's local bounds through the ILocalBounds2DF.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer
member.summary: A layer is a collection of nodes that share a common set of default properties and the same Z-order relative to other layers.

remarks.para: A layer contains zero or more nodes and is responsible for rendering those nodes. Since the nodes in a layer are rendered as a group, their Z-order is the same relative to other layers in the diagram. For example, if layer A has a higher Z-order than layer B, then all nodes in layer B will be rendered behind those in layer A. If the Visible flag on a layer is set to false, none of the nodes in the layer will be rendered.

The nodes in the layer can inherit properties from the layer. If a property is not explicitly set in a node, the node inherits the property from the layer. If the layer does not have the property set, then the layer chains up to the model to get the property. This allows all nodes in a layer to share the same defaults.

Nodes are added to the layer using the method and removed using the method. A node can only belong to one layer at a time. When a node is added to a layer, the layer's is notified so that it can remove it from any other layers that it might already belong to.
All nodes in the layer can be hidden by setting the flag to false.
The Z-order of nodes within a layer can be changed using the following methods: , , , , .

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer.Add(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode)
member.summary: Adds a node the layer.

remarks.para:
If the node already belongs to this layer, this method does nothing. Before adding the node to this layer, this method queries the
object to see if the node already belongs to another layer. If it does, then this method removes the node from that layer.

The node is then added to this layer and the
method is called.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer.Remove(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode)
member.summary: Removes the specified node from this layer.

remarks.para:
If the node does not belong to this layer, this method does nothing. If the node is found and removed from this layer, the
method is called.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer.RemoveAll
member.summary: Removes all nodes from this layer.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer.SetZOrder(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the Z-order of the given node within the layer.

remarks.para:
If the specified node doesn't belong to this layer, this method does nothing. If the node is found, it is removed and re-inserted at the given index position and the
method is called.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Layer.BringForward(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode)
member.summary: Moves the specified node in the layer forward in the Z-order.

remarks.para:
If the specified node doesn't belong to this layer, this method does nothing. If the node is found, it is removed and re-inserted at 1 minus its previous index and the
method is called.

member.summary: Sends the specified node in the layer back in the Z-order.

remarks.para:
If the specified node doesn't belong to this layer, this method does nothing. If the node is found, it is removed and re-inserted at 1 plus its previous index and the
method is called.

member.summary: Brings the specified node in the layer to the front of the Z-order.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model
member.summary: A model is a collection of nodes that are rendered onto a view and manipulated by a controller.

remarks.para: A model is the data portion of a diagram. It is the root node in a hierarchy that is rendered onto a view. This class implements the interface, provides methods for accessing, adding, and removing child nodes. This includes the following methods: , , , , . Child nodes in the model can also be accessed through the property.

A model maintains a collection of layers in the
property. A is a collection of nodes that share a common set of default properties and the same Z-order relative to other layers. A model always contains at least one layer. Each node in the model belongs to one and only one layer. The model renders itself onto the view by iterating through the layers and rendering each one. Each layer is responsible for rendering the nodes belonging to it. The
of the collection is a reference back to the model, which allows the layers to inherit properties from the model. The
property determines which layer a node is assigned to when it is added to the model.
A model contains document-level settings such as , , and .

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.GetConstrainingRegion(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode)
member.summary: Returns the region that the bounds of the given child node is constrained by.
member.param: Child to get constraining region for
member.returns: Region that constrains the bounds of the given child

remarks.para: This method is used to limit the bounds of a child node to a specified area. The node cannot be moved, resized, or rotated beyond the edges of this region.

If the
property is set to true, this method returns a region that matches the bounds of the model. If BoundaryConstraintsEnabled is set to false, then this method returns null. The child parameter is basically ignored, since the implementation is the same for all child nodes. Derived model classes can take advantage of the child parameter to set constraints on a node by node basis.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.GenerateUniqueNodeName(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.INode,System.String@)
member.summary: Called to generate a unique name when inserting a new node.
member.param: Node to generate unique name for
member.returns: true if a new name was generated; false if the name is already unique

remarks.para: The implementation of this method first checks to see if the name is already unique. If it is, then it returns false to the caller and the nodeName parameter contains the original name. If the node's name is not unique within the model, then this method adds a numeric suffix to the name and continues to increment it in a loop until the name is unique. If the nodeName output parameter contains a value other than the original node name, then this method returns true.
This method can be overriden in derived classes in order to customize or replace the algorithm for generating unique names.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.Layers
member.summary: Collection of layers in the model.

remarks.para:
A Layer is a collection of nodes that share a common set of default properties and the same Z-order relative to other layers. A model always contains at least one layer. Each node in the model belongs to one and only one layer. The model renders itself onto the view by iterating through this collection and rendering each layer. Each layer is responsible for rendering the nodes belonging to it. The
of this collection is a reference back to the model, which allows the layers to inherit properties from the model. The DefaultLayer property determines which layer a node is assigned to when it is added to the model.

member.summary: Determines which layer nodes are assigned to when they are added to the model.

member.summary: Name of the default layer.

member.remarks: This flag is set to true when any property of the model changes.

member.summary: Unit of measure used for world coordinates.

member.summary: Scaling ratio between world coordinates and view coordinates.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.BoundaryConstraintsEnabled
member.summary: Indicates if boundary constraints are enabled or not.

remarks.para: This property is true by default. If this property is true, then all nodes in the model are constrained to the bounds of the model. In other words, child nodes cannot move, resize, or rotate to a position that leaves the bounds of the model.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.EventsEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether the model fires events or not.
member.remarks: This property is useful for temporarily disabling events during time critical operations.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.FillStyle
member.summary: Properties used to fill the interior of regions.

remarks.para: The fill style is used to create brushes for painting interior regions of shapes.
The fill style properties in the model are inherited by child nodes. If a child node does not have a value assigned to a given fill style property, then the value assigned to the model is used.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.LineStyle
member.summary: Properties used for drawing lines.

remarks.para: The line style is used to create pens for painting drawing lines.
The line style properties in the model are inherited by child nodes. If a child node does not have a value assigned to a given line style property, then the value assigned to the model is used.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.BackgroundStyle
member.summary: Properties for filling the background of the model.

remarks.para: The background style properties determine how the background of the model will be filled. The BackgroundStyle class is identical to the FillStyle class, with the except that the underlying property names used in the property container are different in order to avoid ambiguity. The FillStyle is used to provide default properties to child nodes. The BackgroundStyle is used by the model in its method.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.PageSettings
member.summary: Page settings to use when creating a print document for the model.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.Parent
member.summary: Reference to the composite node this node is a child of.
member.remarks: If the model is the root node in the hierarchy, this property will be null. The model may also belong to another composite node, in which case the property will reference that composite node.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Model.Root
member.summary: The root node in the node hieararchy.
member.remarks: The root node is found by following the chain of parent nodes until a node is found that has a null parent.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View
member.summary: A view encapsulates a rectangular area inside of a control and renders a onto it.

remarks.para: A view is responsible for rendering the diagram onto a control surface (i.e. window). It contains a reference to a , which contains the data portion of the diagram. The view renders the model onto a System.Drawing.Graphics context object belonging to the control that the view is hosted in. The view also renders other visual cues and decorations that are not persisted in the model, such as selection handles.
The property contains a reference to the control hosting the view.

The view is responsible for conversions between world, view, and device coordinates. The model belongs to the world coordinate space. The view maps world coordinates onto view coordinates by applying its
and
settings, which are used to implement zooming and scrolling. In other words, world coordinates are mapped to view coordinates by applying a transformation that translates to the origin and scales by a magnification percentage. Both world and view coordinates are stored as floating point numbers. View coordinates are mapped to device coordinates based on the
and
settings in the model and the resolution (DPI) of the output device. The default PageUnit setting is Pixel and the default PageScale setting is 1, which results in a 1-1 mapping from view to device coordinates. If the PageUnit is set to Inch, the PageScale is 0.5, and the resolution is 96 dpi then 1 logical unit in view coordinates will equal (1 * 96) * 0.5 = 48 pixels.

The view provides methods for performing hit testing nodes, selection handles, vertices, and ports. The hit testing methods take points in device coordinates and perform the necessary conversion to world coordinates.

The view also provides methods for drawing tracking objects. A tracking object is an outline of a rectangle or shape that is moved or tracked across the screen in response to mouse movements. The view has methods for drawing tracking outlines of rectangles, lines, polygons, curves, and System.Drawing.GraphicsPath objects. These tracking methods are typically used by user interface objects to track mouse movements.

The view contains public methods that can be called to render and repaint onto the host control. The view uses a technique called back buffering, which divides rendering into 2 stages. First, the view renders onto a memory-based bitmap image (the back buffer). The back buffer is then painted onto the host control. This technique eliminates flicker and has the added benefit of leaving the view with an in-memory representation of the last frame it rendered. The back buffer can be accessed through the
property.

The method renders the back buffer and updates the control. The
method takes a portion of the back buffer and draws it onto the host control without re-rendering the back buffer. This is handy for things like tracking, which temporarily clutter up the view and need to repaint it without incurring the overhead of rendering.

member.summary: Renders the view to the parent control.
member.remarks:
This method creates a new System.Drawing.Graphics context for the
and renders the view onto that graphics context object.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Draw(System.Drawing.Graphics)
member.summary: Renders the view onto a System.Drawing.Graphics context object.
member.param: Graphics context object to render to

remarks.para: This method first renders the view onto the back buffer. It fills the buffer with the view's background color, draws the grid and page bounds, and then draws the model. Then paints the back buffer onto the graphics context.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Refresh(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Transfers a rectangular area of the back buffer onto the parent control.
member.param: Bounding rectangle of area to refresh

remarks.para: This method is used to repaint an area of the parent control without rendering the back buffer. It uses the current contents of the back buffer and draws it onto a rectangular area of the parent control.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Refresh
member.summary: Transfers the back buffer onto the parent control.

remarks.para: This method is used to repaint the view onto the parent control without rendering the back buffer. It uses the current contents of the back buffer and draws it onto the parent control.

member.summary: Looks for a resize handle at the given point.

Position of the resize handle hit
member.returns: Reference to the node that contains the handle or null if no resize handle was found at the given point

remarks.para: This method returns null if a resize handle is not found at the specified point. If a resize handle is found, then it returns the node that owns the resize handle and the position of the resize handle is returned in the handlePos parameter.

Index position of the vertex hit
member.returns: Reference to the node that contains the vertex or null if no vertex handle was found at the given point

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Origin
member.summary: Logical origin of the view in world coordinates.

remarks.para: This property moves the view relative to the world coordinate space. The value specifies a point in the world coordinate space that corresponds to the top left corner of the view.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.VirtualSize
member.summary: Returns the size of the scrollable area in device coordinates.

remarks.para: The value returned is the width and height of the model converted to device coordinates. If there is no model attached to the view at the time of the call, then the size of the view is returned instead.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Magnification
member.summary: Specifies the X and Y magnification (zoom) values on a scale of 1 to n.

remarks.para: This value is used to zoom the view in and out. The X and Y axes can be scaled independently. Normally, the X and Y axes will have the same magnification value.
The value of this property along with the are used to create the view transform, which is used to map world coordinates onto view coordinates.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.SelectionList
member.summary: List of currently selected nodes.
member.remarks: Contains a reference to the controller's selection list. This property is assigned by the controller it attaches to the view.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.SelectionAnchorNode
member.summary: Node in the selection list that acts as the anchor.

remarks.para: The anchor node is always the last node in the selection list.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.BackgroundColor
member.summary: The color used to clear the view before rendering the diagram.

remarks.para: The background of the view is the region outside of the visible diagram.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.HandleSize
member.summary: Size of selection handles specified in device coordinates.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.HandleColor
member.summary: Color used to drawing selection handles.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.HandleAnchorColor
member.summary: Color used for handles of anchor node.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.SelectHandleMode

member.remarks: This property supports vertex editing mode.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Grid
member.summary: Grid of evenly spaced points that provide a visual guide to the user.

remarks.para: Draws a matrix of evenly spaced points in the view and provides snap to grid calculations.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.GridType
member.summary: Determines the type of grid presented in the view.

remarks.para: The choices are either Point or Line.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.ShowPageBounds
member.summary: Determines if page bounds are displayed in the view or not.

remarks.para: If this property is set to true, then lines are drawn in the view to mark the boundaries of pages. The size of the model and settings for the current default printer determine how many pages the diagram contains.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.Cursor
member.summary: Cursor currently used in the view.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.TrackingStyle
member.summary: Line style for tracking.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.View.DrawingSurface
member.summary: The back buffer used for rendering.

remarks.para: The drawing surface is a bitmap on which the view renders itself before drawing it to the parent control. It is an in memory representation of the last frame rendered by the view. It can be accessed and drawn to directly.
NOTE: The terms drawing surface and back buffer are used interchangeably.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack
member.summary: This class implements a stack collection for Matrix objects.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a matrix stack.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.Push(System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix)
member.summary: Push the given matrix onto the stack.
member.param: Matrix to push onto the stack
member.returns: Result matrix
member.remarks: The matrix is passed in is combined with the matrix on the top of the stack to produce the return value. The matrices are combined using matrix multiplication, where the incoming matrix is appended to the matrix on the top of the stack. If the stack is empty, then the matrix passed in is returned.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.Push(System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix,System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder)
member.summary: Push the given matrix onto the stack given a matrix order to produce the result.
member.param: Matrix to push onto the stack
Order in which multiplication will take place when generating the result matrix
member.returns: Result matrix

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.Peek
member.summary: Return the matrix on the top of the stack.
member.returns: Matrix on top of the stack

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.Pop
member.summary: Removes the matrix on the top from the stack and returns it.
member.returns: Matrix popped from the stack

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.MatrixStack.Clear
member.summary: Remove all matrix objects from the stack.

member.summary: Conversions between logical units of measure.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Measurements.InitScreenDPI
member.summary: Gets the screen resolution and saves it for use in conversions.

remarks.para: Conversions that involve the Graphics.Pixel unit of measure require the DPI (dots per inch) to convert to and from real-world units of measure. This method gets the screen resolution by creating a System.Drawing.Graphics object for the screen and then it stores the X and Y DPI for later use in calculations.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Shape
member.summary: A shape is a leaf node that encapsulates a drawing primitive such as a rectangle, line, ellipse, or polygon. is a drawing primitive such as encapsulates a graphics object that is represented by a GDI+ GraphicsPath.
member.remarks: The Shape class implements the interface and contains a GDI+ GraphicsPath object. This class is an abstract base class from which specific shapes are implemented. The contained GraphicsPath object is contains provides rendering and hit testing for the shape.

member.summary: Bounding box of the shape in local coordinates.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.OrthogonalLine
member.summary: Implements orthogonal lines.

remarks.para: An orthogonal line is a series of line segments that are joined together with right (90 degree) angles. All of the line segments in an orthogonal line are parallel to either the X or Y axis of the world coordinate space.
When a vertex is changed, added, or removed from the orthogonal line, the remaining vertices are recalculated to keep the line orthogonal.

member.summary: Called when a property is changed.

remarks.para:
This method notifies the
of the property change by calling the parent node's
method.
This method also recalculates the points in the orthogonal line if one of the following properties was changed: , , , , , .

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.OrthogonalLine.AutomaticHeadings
member.summary: Determines if the compass headings of the endpoints are automatically calculated.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.OrthogonalLine.HeadingEndPoint1
member.summary: Compass heading of the first endpoint.

remarks.para: The compass heading can be North, South, East, or West. The compass headings of the first and last endpoints determine how many segments are needed to join the two endpoints using orthogonal lines.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.OrthogonalLine.HeadingEndPoint2
member.summary: Compass heading of the second endpoint.

remarks.para: The compass heading can be North, South, East, or West. The compass headings of the first and last endpoints determine how many segments are needed to join the two endpoints using orthogonal lines.

member.summary: Create a rectangle from 2 points.
member.returns: Rectangle

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Geometry.GetOrthogonalPoint(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Drawing.PointF,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns a point orthogonal to the two endpoints of the line.
member.param: Row number of point to calculate
Column number of point to calculate
member.returns: A logical point that is orthogonal to the two line endpoints
member.remarks: The row and column are used to index a 5x5 matrix of points that surround the two endpoints. All of the points in the matrix are orthogonal to the endpoints. The matrix can be thought of as two rectangles and a point in the center. The outer rectangle contains 16 points and the inner rectangle contains 8 points (16+8+1=25). The endpoints always lie in either the 2nd or 4th column and the 2nd or 4th row. In other words, the endpoints are always two of the four corners of the inner rectangle. The outer rectangle is calculated by inflating the inner rectangle using the padding value passed in.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Geometry.CalcEndpointDirections(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Drawing.PointF,Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CompassHeading@,Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.CompassHeading@)
member.summary: Calculate the optimal directions for the two specified points.
member.param: Heading calculated for the first point
Heading calculated for the second point
member.remarks: This method is used for orthogonal lines. Given two points, this method determines the compass headings for the two points. The compass heading for each point determines which direction the line will attach to the point.

member.summary: A style is an object that encapsulates one or more properties in a property container.
member.remarks: Style objects provide a wrapper for a collection of properties in a property container. Getting and setting properties through a style object is easier than doing it through the IPropertyContainer interface because the style object provides type-safe wrappers for each property. The properties exposed through a style object are also browsable in the property grid.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Port
member.summary: A port is a point on a symbol on which connections can be established.

remarks.para: Each port is owned by a port container and may have zero or more connections hooked up to it. A port container is an object that implements the interface. The port container is typically either a or a .

This is an abstract base class from which different implementations are derived. Positioning and visual representation of a port is determined by classes derived from this one. For example, a renders itself as a circle containing crosshairs and can be positioned anywhere within the bounds of the port container. A is invisible and always positions itself at the center of its port container.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Connection
member.summary: A connection is an object that binds two ports together.

remarks.para:
A connection consists of two ports: a source port and a target port. The distinction between the source port and target port is not really signficant, because a connection doesn't have a direction. The names source and target could just as easily be Port1 and Port2. The two ports involved in the connection can be accessed through the
and
properties.

Each port is owned by an object that implements the
interface, which will typically be either a
or a . A port container has methods for accessing the ports and connections it contains, and it has methods that are called by connections in order to notify the port container of events that affect the connection. For example, the
method is called by a connection to notify a port container that the other port container it is connected to has moved.

This class contains methods to help navigate from one port container to another. The
method takes a port container as a parameter and returns the either the or the , depending on which one belongs to the given container. The
method does the reverse. It returns the port that does not belong to the given port container.

member.returns: Port belonging to the given port container

member.returns: Port not belonging to the given port container

remarks.para: If the SourcePort belongs to the given port container, then the TargetPort is returned. If the TargetPort belongs to the given port container, then the SourcePort is returned.

method on the foreign port container. The foreign port container is the port container that is not the one passed in as a parameter.

interface. The and
classes are both derived from SymbolBase, and therefore are label containers.

method to request its position.

member.summary: Indicates if text should be wrapped when it exceeds the width of the bounding box.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.DirectionRightToLeft
member.summary: Specifies that text is right to left.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.DirectionVertical
member.summary: Specifies that text is vertical.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.FitBlackBox
member.summary: Specifies that no part of any glyph overhangs the bounding rectangle.

remarks.para: By default some glyphs overhang the rectangle slightly where necessary to appear at the edge visually. For example when an italic lowercase letter f in a font such as Garamond is aligned at the far left of a rectangle, the lower part of the f will reach slightly further left than the left edge of the rectangle. Setting this flag will ensure no painting outside the rectangle but will cause the aligned edges of adjacent lines of text to appear uneven.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.LineLimit
member.summary: Only entire lines are laid out in the formatting rectangle.

remarks.para: By default layout continues until the end of the text, or until no more lines are visible as a result of clipping, whichever comes first. Note that the default settings allow the last line to be partially obscured by a formatting rectangle that is not a whole multiple of the line height. To ensure that only whole lines are seen, specify this value and be careful to provide a formatting rectangle at least as tall as the height of one line.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.MeasureTrailingSpaces
member.summary: Include space at the end of each line in calculations that measure the size of the text.

remarks.para: By default the boundary rectangle returned by the MeasureString method excludes the space at the end of each line. Set this flag to include that space in measurement.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.TextBase.NoClip
member.summary: Overhanging parts of glyphs, and unwrapped text reaching outside the formatting rectangle are allowed to show.

remarks.para: By default all text and glyph parts reaching outside the formatting rectangle are clipped.

remarks.para: See System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags for more details.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Link
member.summary: A link is a composite node that supports labels and connections to other symbols.

remarks.para:
A link is a special type of symbol that has two built-in ports: a
and a . The head and tail port define the direction of the link.

The head and tail ports are anchored to the first child node belonging to the link (at index position 0), which is referred to as the link shape. The link shape can be any type of node, the only requirement being that it must support the interface. The tail port is anchored to the first vertex in the link shape and the head port is anchored to the last point in the link shape.

The link shape is created by the
method, which is virtual and can overridden by derived classes. The CreateLinkShape method is passed a enumeration, which defines a set of built-in link shapes to choose from. The CreateLinkShape method is also passed an array of points to load into the link shape. The default implementation of the CreateLinkShape method maps the enumeration onto a specified type of shape node, and then creates an instance of that type and loads it with the array of points. Derived classes can override CreateLinkShape and interpret the parameters however they like, as long as it returns a valid object that supports the IPoints interface.

Like symbols, links may contain labels. Labels are accessible through the collection. The class implements a special type of label that can orient itself along a line or curve by specifying the a percentage value along the link. Setting the
property of a LinkLabel will position the label at the tail of the link. Setting it to 100 will position the label at the head of the link. Values in between position the label somewhere between the head and tail.
The link class implements the interface, which is used in conjunction with the interface to navigate the node hierarchy as a graph of interconnected nodes and edges.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase
member.summary: Base class for symbols and links.

remarks.para: This class provides the base implementation for both symbols and links. Symbols and links are similar in they are both composite nodes that contain ports and labels. Both implement the interface, which exposes a collection of ports and supports connections to other port containers. When discussing ports and connections, symbols and links are frequently referred to as "port containers".
One key difference between symbols and links is that links have two built-in ports: a head port and a tail port. Therefore, a link has a direction and a symbol does not.

Another difference between symbols and links is the way in which they behave during graph navigation. Symbols implement the interface and links implement the interface. This means that when the node hierarchy is navigated as a graph, symbols are nodes and links are edges.

The documentation in this class uses the term "symbol" to mean both symbols and links. Refer to the documentation for the
class and the
class for more details.

member.summary: Tests to see if a connection between the two given ports is allowed.

The default implementation always returns true. This method can be overridden in derived classes.

member.summary: Create a new connection between the given ports.
member.returns: New connection object or null on failure

remarks.para:
This method first calls the
method on each port in order to ask permission to create the connection. If both ports consent to the connection, a new object is created to bind the two ports together. Then the connection is added to the
collection of both port containers.

remarks.para: A connection consists of two ports. The local port on a connection is the one that belongs to this symbol. The foreign port is the one that belongs to the other symbol.

member.summary: Returns the port referenced by the given connection that belongs to the foreign symbol.

remarks.para: A connection consists of two ports. The local port on a connection is the one that belongs to this symbol. The foreign port is the one that belongs to the other symbol.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.ForeignContainerAdd(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Connection)
member.summary: Adds the specified connection to the foreign port container.

remarks.para: A connection binds together two ports on two separate port containers (symbol, link, etc). The local port container is the one that owns this collection. The foreign port container is the other one involved in the connection. Both port containers maintain a list of the connections and must be kept synchronized. This method ensures that the given connection is added to the foreign port container, if it is not already there.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.ForeignContainerRemove(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Connection)
member.summary: Removes the specified connection from the foreign port container.

remarks.para: A connection binds together two ports on two separate port containers (symbol, link, etc). The local port container is the one that owns this collection. The foreign port container is the other one involved in the connection. Both port containers maintain a list of the connections and must be kept synchronized. This method ensures that the given connection is removed from the foreign port container, if it is there.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.CalcLabelPosition(Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Label)
member.summary: Calculates the point at which the given label should be positioned.
member.remarks: This method is called by the label itself in order to find out where it should be positioned.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.GetLabelTransform(System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix)
member.summary: Builds a world transformation matrix for a label.
member.param: Local transformation matrix of a label
member.returns: World transformation matrix
member.remarks: This method prepends the symbol's parent transformation to the incoming matrix and returns the result. The purpose of doing this is to avoid including the symbol's local transformation matrix in the label's world transformation matrix. This prevents labels from being scaled and rotated when the symbol to which they are attached is scaled or rotated.

member.summary: Fully qualified name of the node.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.ChildCount

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.Bounds
member.summary: The symbol's bounding box.

remarks.para: Always returns the bounds of the symbol in world coordinates, regardless of what is on the matrix stack at the time of the call.

The bounding box of a symbol is the union of the bounds of all of its children. This method pushes the symbol's
onto the matrix stack and then iterates through each child retrieving it's local bounds through the ILocalBounds2DF.

member.name: P:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolBase.Syncfusion#Windows#Forms#Diagram#ILocalBounds2DF#Bounds
member.summary: Bounding box of the symbol in local coordinates.
member.remarks: The value returned depends on the contents of the matrix stack. If the matrix stack is empty, then the value returned is in local coordinates. This method is generally used by functions that recursively traverse the node hierarchy, pushing and popping the matrix stack as they go.

member.name: M:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Link.DockConnections
member.summary: Adjusts the endpoints of the link so that they are docked with the foreign ports they are connected to.

remarks.para: This method iterates through every connection in the link. For each connection, the location of the local port is updated to match the location of the foreign port. If the foreign port has its AttachAtPerimeter flag set to true, then some additional calculations are made in order to move the local port to the perimeter of the foreign port's container.

member.summary: The port anchored to the entry point of the link.

The head and tail ports of a link define the direction of the link. The head port is the exit point for a link.

member.summary: The port anchored to the exit point of the link.

The head and tail ports of a link define the direction of the link. The tail port is the entry point for a link.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Symbol
member.summary: A symbol is a composite node that supports labels and connections to other symbols and links.

remarks.para: Shapes, text, images, and other types of nodes can be aggregated together in a symbol. A symbol draws itself by drawing all of its child nodes, so its appearance is determined by union of all its children. The bounds of a symbol are also determined by the union of all its child nodes. The position and size of child nodes is always relative to the symbol.

Symbol may contain one or more ports positioned anywhere within its bounds. A port is a point at which connections to other symbols and links can be established. NOTE: A link is a special type of symbol that contains a shape (typically a line or polyline) and two ports on each end. Much of the information about symbols is also applicable to links. A is an object that binds two ports together and establishes a connection between two symbols. Symbols that are connected co-operate by send messages to each other when certain events occur, such as movement or resizing.
All symbols contain a , which is a port that is always positioned at the center of the symbol's bounds.

Symbols can be connected to other symbols and links using the
method, which creates a new object and wires it up to the ports provided. The port belonging to the symbol object the Connect method was invoked on is referred to as the local port, and the port belonging to the symbol to which the connection is being made is referred to as the foreign port. In other words, the foreign port belongs to "this" symbol and the foreign port belongs to "the other" symbol. When a new connection is created, it is added to both the local symbol and the foreign symbol so that they both know about the connection. This is done automatically by the Connect method.

Connections can be destroyed by calling the
method.

A symbol may contain one or more labels. A
is a type of text object that is anchored to a symbol. A label is positioned by specifying a that corresponds to the bounding box of the symbol the label belongs to. The property of a label can either be bound to an independent value maintained by the label or it can be bound to any property in the symbol it belongs to. This is very useful for creating a label that displays the symbol name or some property of the symbol.
Labels can be added to a symbol using the method. Labels call back to the symbol through the interface in order to position themselves relative to the symbol.
The symbol class implements the interface, which is used in conjunction with the interface to navigate the node hierarchy as a graph of interconnected nodes and edges.

A symbol can be created from a , which is a model containing nodes and properties to be applied the symbol. The Symbol Designer application creates symbol models and stores them inside of a . A symbol palette is a collection of related symbol models.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.SymbolModel
member.summary: Design-time representation of a symbol.

remarks.para: This class encapsulates the data used to create a symbol. It is a model that contains nodes and properties that are used to create and initialize symbols. A symbol model can contain shapes, text, images, and other types of nodes which are copied into new symbols created from it.

The method is called to create instances of symbols from the symbol model. The runtime type created by CreateSymbol is determined by the
and
properties, which are set by default to create
objects. The PlugInAssembly and PlugInClass properties allow developers to plugin their own derived implementations of the Symbol class.

After the
method instantiates the symbol specified by the PlugInAssembly and PlugInClass properties, it populates with the nodes and properties contained by the symbol model.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.Tool
member.summary: Base class for user interface tools.

remarks.para:
A tool is an object that receives input from a controller and implements a piece of functionality or feature. Tools are helper objects that plug into a controller. Tools are attached to a controller using the
method. Each tool has a , which must be unique within a controller. The
method in the controller can be used to lookup a tool by name.

Activation and deactivation of tools is coordinated by the controller. The
method activates a given tool. The controller notifies all other tools about the activation. The
method is called by the controller when another tool is being activated, which gives the tool the opportunity to either suspend or cancel what it is doing. The
method is called by the controller when another tool is being deactivated, which gives the tool the opportunity to resume what it was doing prior to being suspended.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.RectangleToolBase
member.summary: Base class for tools that draw tracking rectangles.

remarks.para:
This class provides a base implementation for tools that require the user to draw a rectangle. When a mouse down event is received, the point at which the event occurred becomes the first point in the rectangle. As the mouse moves, the rectangle is tracked. When a mouse up event is received, this class calls the
method which is implemented by derived classes.

member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Forms.Diagram.NodePathTracker
member.summary: Tracks the graphics paths of a collection of nodes.

remarks.para:
This class implements a node tracker the draws the outline of the regions of a collection of nodes. In other words, this class tracks the actual outline of the object - not just the bounding boxes. A System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath object is created for each node by calling the node's
method. Nodes that do not support the
interface are tracked using their bounding boxes.
